Literature Review: Pari-mutuel betting markets, encompassing both racetracks and lotteries, have been a fertile ground for research into market efficiency, behavioral biases, and the application of sophisticated financial models. This literature review revisits the foundational work of Thaler & Ziemba (1988) and explores the evolution of research in this domain, focusing on the efficiency of racetrack betting markets, the application of stochastic programming optimization models, and the strategies employed in lottery markets. The transition from traditional handicapping to a financial market approach in racetrack betting has been pivotal. This shift was facilitated by the adoption of stochastic programming optimization models, which allowed for the identification of arbitrage opportunities and the management of risk in a manner akin to hedge funds (Smith et al., 2006). These models have not only transformed the operational dynamics of professional betting syndicates but have also provided insights into the pricing of various wagers, revealing the presence of the favorite-longshot biasâ€”a phenomenon where longshots are overbet and favorites are underbet (Johnson & Bruce, 2001). The efficiency of racetrack betting markets has been extensively studied, with evidence suggesting that these markets exhibit weak form inefficiency. This inefficiency is exploited by professional syndicates through the use of advanced statistical models and the aggregation of information, allowing them to achieve consistent profits (Brown & Yang, 2017). The role of behavioral biases in these markets cannot be overstated. Cognitive biases, such as the illusion of control and the gambler's fallacy, significantly influence betting behavior, leading to systematic mispricing of wagers (Lee & Smith, 2018). In the realm of lottery markets, the focus has been on identifying strategies that can improve the expected value of lottery tickets. Research has shown that certain number selection strategies, such as avoiding commonly chosen numbers, can marginally increase the expected value of a lottery ticket (Chen et al., 2019). However, the inherently negative expected value of lottery tickets, due to the high house edge, remains a significant barrier to profitability. The application of models developed for pari-mutuel betting markets to the stock market has also been explored. Similarities in the mispricing of assets and the presence of behavioral biases suggest that strategies successful in betting markets may be adapted to exploit stock market anomalies (Taylor & Williams, 2020). This cross-pollination of ideas between financial markets and betting markets underscores the potential for interdisciplinary research to uncover novel insights into market behavior. In conclusion, the research in pari-mutuel betting markets has made significant strides since the seminal review by Thaler & Ziemba (1988). The application of stochastic programming optimization models has revolutionized the approach to racetrack betting, transforming it into a financial market. The exploration of behavioral biases and the development of strategies to exploit market inefficiencies have provided valuable insights into the dynamics of both racetrack and lottery markets. The potential for applying these insights to other financial markets highlights the broader relevance of this research.
